entry.title: The Latest: Queen Elizabeth II shocked about Tunisia attack
entry.summary: An Irish mother-of-two, Lorna Carty, was earlier confirmed as a victim of Friday's attack on the Sousse beach resort in Tunisia.

entry.title: The Latest: Queen Elizabeth II shocked about Tunisia attack
entry.summary:
A book and flowers lay at the scene of the attack in Sousse, Tunisia, Sunday, June 28, 2015.

Boys play on the beach while tourists and residents, some displaying a Tunisian flag, walk on the beach to the scene of the attack in Sousse, Tunisia, Sunday, June 28, 2015.

Britain's home secretary says the number of Britons confirmed killed in the Tunisia beach resort attack is expected to rise.

entry.title: Tunisia deploys 100,000 security personnel to avert attacks
entry.summary: Tunisia's government says it has deployed 100,000 security personnel to protect the country and prevent new attacks, including 3,000 dedicated to protecting beaches, hotels and archaeological sites.

entry.title: Tunisia says it's doing all it can to protect foreign tourists
entry.summary: Hundreds of thousands of Britons visit Tunisia each year.

entry.title: Tunis recoils, as Britain tells its citizens to flee Tunisia
entry.summary: The 30 Britons who died in Sousse were Thomson and First Choice customers and the operators - both owned by TUI Group - have no travelers in Tunisia.

entry.title: Tunisia Britons fly home after alert
entry.summary: Thomas Cook, which has cancelled all bookings to Tunisia until the October date, said it was putting on an extra flight on Friday to bring customers back to the UK.

entry.title: Tunisia defends efforts to protect British tourists
entry.summary: Tunisia's prime minister says that his country has done "everything in our power" to protect British and other foreign tourists, as British travelers flock to Tunisian airports under orders from their government to flee amid risks of terror attacks.

entry.title: Tunisia defends efforts to protect British tourists
entry.summary: Britain on Thursday told all U.K. tourists to leave Tunisia, saying the North African country hasn't done enough to enhance security.

entry.title: Tunisia defends efforts to protect British tourists
British government tells tourists: Leave Tunisia
entry.summary: In a statement, his office said the travel advice had been changed because "we do not believe the mitigation measures in place provide adequate protection for British tourists in Tunisia."

entry.title: U.K. tells tourists to leave Tunisia, says attack 'highly likely'
entry.summary: "If you're in Tunisia and you don't have an essential need to remain you should leave by commercial means," the statement said.

entry.title: Britain marking 10th anniversary of 7July bombings
entry.summary: He said: "The murder of 30 innocent Britons whilst holidaying in Tunisia is a brutal reminder of that fact. But we will never be cowed by terrorism."

entry.title: UK remembers 2005 London bombings under shadow of Tunisia
entry.summary: London (AFP) - Britain will on Tuesday mark 10 years since the London bombings with a minute's silence for the 52 victims, less than a fortnight after an attack in Tunisia highlighted the ongoing Islamist threat.

entry.title: Tunisia declares state of emergency after beach attack
entry.summary:
Tunisia has faced a post-revolution surge in jihadist violence in which dozens of police and soldiers have been killed.

The jihadist attacks have dealt a heavy blow to the tourism industry, which contributes between seven and eight percent of Tunisia's GDP.

entry.title: Tunisia declares state of emergency after deadly beach hotel
entry.summary: With a nationwide televised address, President Beji Caid Essebsi officially reintroduced urgent security measures for Tunisia that had been lifted in March 2014.

entry.title: State of emergency declared in Tunisia
entry.summary: Tunisia's government has promised new laws to increase police powers and provide for harsher penalties for terrorism convictions.

entry.title: Tunisia imposes state of emergency after deadly beach attack
entry.summary:
Tunisia's state news agency says the country's president is declaring a state of emergency more than a week after a beach attack targeting foreign tourists that killed 38 people.

Tunisia's president declared a state of emergency on Saturday in response to a second deadly attack on foreigners in three months, saying the country is "not safe" and risks collapse from further extremist attacks.

entry.title: Tunisia imposes state of emergency after deadly beach attack
entry.summary: Tunisia was under a state of emergency from January 2011, at the outbreak of the Arab Spring, until March 2014.

entry.title: Tunisia President Declares State of Emergency
entry.summary: "Tunisia faces a very serious danger and it should take any possible measures to maintain security and safety," he said.

entry.title: Tunisia declares state of emergency
entry.summary: Mr Essebsi blamed the poor security in Libya for Tunisia's problems, and the lack of international resolve in targeting the Islamic State group throughout the region.

entry.title: Silence remembers Tunisia attack dead
entry.summary: The British ambassador to Tunisia, Hamish Cowell, laid a wreath on the beach.

entry.title: Britain, Tunisia honor 38 victims of beach resort attack
entry.summary:
People observe the minute silence for the victims of the shooting in Tunisia last week, at the All England Lawn Tennis Championships in Wimbledon, London, Friday July 3, 2015.

Fans and staff at Wimbledon observed a minute's silence for the victims of last Friday's attack in Tunisia, in which 30 Britons were killed in a shooting rampage at a beach resort in Sousse.

entry.title: Britain, Tunisia honor 38 victims of beach resort attack
entry.summary: Flags have been lowered to half-staff at Buckingham Palace and U.K. government buildings as Britain and Tunisia honor the 38 victims of an Islamic extremist's rampage at a Tunisian beach resort.

entry.title: Britain falls silent to remember 30 killed in Tunisian gun attack
entry.summary:
A Union flag flies at half-mast on Buckingham Palace in London, to mark an official day of mourning a week since the deadly Tunisia beach attack.

The coffin of Denis Thwaites is carried from an RAF C-17, which repatriated the bodies of eight British nationals killed in the Tunisia terror attack, at RAF Brize Norton near Oxford.

entry.title: Tunisia beach hotel attack: 12 arrested in connection with massacre
Tunisia beach attack: the victims
entry.summary: Karl Turner, the MP for East Hull, tweeted: "So sorry Claire Windass from Hull was killed in Tunisia terrorist attack. My thoughts with family & friends. RIP."

entry.title: Tunisia attack: Bodies of all but one of the British victims identified, according to Government
entry.summary: "I can confirm that the number of Britons killed in the Tunisia terrorist attack who have been positively identified has now reached 29," Mr Hammond said.

entry.title: Tunisia gunman Saif Rezgui trained in Libya at same time as Bardo museum killers
entry.summary:
Tunis: The Tunisian gunman who carried out a deadly attack on a hotel last Friday trained in a jihadist camp in Libya last year, Tunisia's government said on Tuesday.

Tunisia's Health Ministry said on Tuesday it had so far identified 33 bodies from Friday's violence, including 25 British, three Irish, one Belgian, two German, a Russian citizen and a Portuguese national.

Tunisia expects to lose at least $670 million this year, or about a quarter of its estimated annual tourism earnings, following last Friday's attack.

entry.title: Tunisia beach gunman trained in Libya with museum attackers: Official
entry.summary:
The revelation confirms repeated fears that the strong presence of the Islamic State group in neighbouring Libya has become a direct threat to Tunisia, the only democracy to emerge from the Arab Spring uprisings.

Increasingly, however, they have stayed in Libya before returning to carry out attacks in Tunisia.

Tunisia's most well-known Islamic radical Seifallah Ben Hassine, fled to Libya in 2013 taking many supporters with him into exile.

entry.title: APNewsBreak: Tunisia beach killer trained with museum gunmen
Tunisia attack: gunman Seifeddine Rezgu 'trained in Libya at same time as Bardo museum attackers'
entry.summary: Mr Essebsi, 88, is a veteran of Tunisia's pre-revolutionary regime and was elected last autumn on a platform of restoring security and dignity to the state.

entry.title: Tunisia chief: New security system had been set for July 1
entry.summary: Friday's attack, Tunisia's worst terrorist incident, is expected to cripple the vital tourism sector, with the tourism minister predicting a half billion dollars in losses for 2015.

entry.title: Tunisia chief: New security system had been set for July 1
entry.summary: British Minister for North Africa Tobias Ellwood, leaves from local hospital in Tunis, Tunisia, Tuesday, June 30, 2015.

entry.title: Solidarity keeps some tourists in Tunisia after terrorist attack
entry.summary: Sousse: At a makeshift memorial on the site of last Friday's deadly attack, a steady stream of tourists and locals gathered to lay flowers and notes to remember the victims of Tunisia's worst ever terror attack.

entry.title: Tunisia makes first beach attack arrests as UK urges fightback
Solidarity keeps some tourists in Tunisia after terrorist attack
entry.summary: There were reports that up to 10,000 of the 20,000 Britons holidaying in Tunisia have left since Friday's attack, with tour companies arranging extra flights for tourists desperate to flee.

entry.title: Tunisia arrests suspects associated with beach hotel attacker
entry.summary:
They promised Tunisia help in security, intelligence, police training and to help keep tourism alive.

British police are in Tunisia helping in the process of formally identifying victims.

Tour companies have helped thousands of tourists leave Tunisia since Friday's attack on a country that relies heavily on tourism for jobs and foreign currency revenues.

entry.title: Tunisia arrests suspects associated with beach hotel attacker
Tunisian authorities hunt accomplices of gunman
entry.summary: The attacker has been identified as Seifeddine Rezgui, a 24-year-old graduate of Tunisia's Kairouan University where he had been living with the other students.

entry.title: The Latest: Queen Elizabeth II shocked about Tunisia attack
entry.summary:
Police officers patrol on the beach of Sousse, Tunisia, Sunday, June 28, 2015.

Tunisia's top security official says 1,000 extra police are being deployed at tourist sites and beaches in the North African nation after Friday's attack.

A Tunisian police officer guards the beach area in front of the attacked Imperial Marhaba Hotel in Sousse, Tunisia, Sunday, June 28, 2015.

Queen Elizabeth II says the attack on a beach resort in Tunisia has left her and her husband, Prince Philip, shocked.

entry.title: Young Soccer Player, Blogger Among Those Killed in Tunisia
entry.summary: So did Ross Nayler, whose father, 42-year-old Scott Chaulkley, was on holiday in Tunisia together with Davey.

entry.title: European tour operators evacuate thousands from Tunisia after attack
entry.summary:
SOUSSE, Tunisia Tour companies were evacuating thousands of foreign holidaymakers from Tunisia on Saturday, a day after a gunman killed 39 people at a beach hotel in an attack claimed by Islamic State.

Tour operators Thomson and First Choice, which are owned by German travel group TUI, said they had about 6,400 customers across Tunisia at the time of the attack, including several of the people killed and injured.

entry.title: Terror on the beach: Tourists recount Tunisia attack horrors
entry.summary: No one grasped what was happening at first in what became Tunisia's worst terrorist attack.

entry.title: Dozens killed in attacks in Tunisia, Kuwait and France
entry.summary:
Since overthrowing its secular dictator in 2011, Tunisia has been plagued by terrorist attacks, although only recently have they targeted the tourism sector, which makes up nearly 15 percent of GDP.

The attacks are also a blow to Tunisia's image as a stable, democratic nation emerging from its revolution in 2011, said Jonathan Hill, a professor of Defense Studies at King's College in London.

entry.title: Dozens killed in attacks in Tunisia, Kuwait and France
entry.summary: A pool of blood is seen on the ground near the area where a terrorist attack took place in the coastal town of Sousse, Tunisia, Friday June 26, 2015.

entry.title: Dozens killed in attacks in Tunisia, Kuwait and France
entry.summary: Injured people are treated near the area where an attack took place in Sousse, Tunisia, Friday June 26, 2015.

entry.title: Dozens killed in attacks in Tunisia, Kuwait and France
entry.summary: In Britain, police said they were tightening security at major events after the attacks in France, Kuwait and Tunisia, including for the weekend events of Armed Forces Day and the Pride London gay and lesbian festival.

entry.title: The Latest: US condemns attacks in France, Kuwait, Tunisia
entry.summary:
White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest says "the United States condemns in the strongest terms the terrorist attacks in France, Kuwait and Tunisia today."

The international police agency Interpol is offering its investigative help to Tunisia, France, Kuwait and Somalia after separate attacks that have killed more than 80 people.

The French attack Friday came on the same day as a gunman mowed down scores of tourists on a beach in Tunisia and a suicide bomber killed over two dozen worshippers at a Shiite mosque in Kuwait.

entry.title: David Cameron: Britain to stand with France and Tunisia against terrorism
entry.summary: These events have taken place today in Tunisia and France but they could happen anywhere.

entry.title: Shootings at Tunisia resort, beheading in France, bombing in Kuwait
entry.summary: "I am sickened by the attacks in Tunisia, France and Kuwait," Cameron tweeted.

entry.title: Gunmen open fire at Sousse, Tunisia, hotel; 37 dead
